sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• evaluate serum chemistry, including renal and hepatic function, prior to the first dose in each cycle and ensure the absolute neutrophil count is 1 x 10(9)/L or greater and platelet count is 50 x 10(9)/L or greater
  • Peripheral T-cell lymphoma (clinical), Relapsed or refractory: 1000 mg/m(2) IV infusion over 30 minutes on days 1 through 5 of a 21-day cycle, repeated until disease progression or toxicity
  • Peripheral T-cell lymphoma (clinical), Relapsed or refractory: homozygous for UGT1A1*28 al≤: initial dose, 750 mg/m(2) IV infusion over 30 minutes on days 1 through 5 of a 21-day cycle, repeated until disease progression or toxicity

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy have not been established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment, CrCl 39 mL/min or less: insufficient data to recommend a dose
  • hepatic impairment, moderate to severe: insufficient data to recommend a dose
  • neutropenia (absolute neutrophile count [ANC] nadir 0.5 x 10(9)/L or less with any platelet count): interrupt and resume with a decrease in dose of 25% [750 mg/m(2)] only when ANC is 1 x 10(9)/L or greater and platelet count is 50 x 10(9)/L or greater
  • recurrent neutropenia (ANC nadir less than 0.5 x 10(9)/L with any platelet count): after 2 dosage reductions, discontinue use
  • thrombocytopenia (platelet count less then 25 x 10(9)/L with any ANC nadir): interrupt and resume with a decrease in dose of 25% [750 mg/m(2)] only when platelet count is 50 x 10(9)/L or greater and ANC is 1 x 10(9)/L or greater
  • recurrent thrombocytopenia (platelet count less then 25 x 10(9)/L plus any ANC nadir): after 2 dose reductions, discontinue use
  • nonhematologic toxicities (grade 3 or 4), excluding nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea: interrupt and resume with a decrease in dose of 25% [750 mg/m(2)] only when the toxicity is grade 2 or less
  • nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea (grade 3 or 4) with duration longer than 7 days despite supportive management: interrupt and resume with a decrease in dose of 25% [750 mg/m(2)] only when the toxicity is grade 2 or less
  • recurrent nonhematologic toxicities (grade 3 or 4): after 2 dose reductions, discontinue use

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Peripheral T-cell lymphoma (clinical), Relapsed or refractory

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Gastrointestinal:
  • -- nausea, vomiting and diarrhea have been reported; antiemetic and antidiarrheal medications may be necessary
  • Hematologic:
  • -- thrombocytopenia, leukopenia (neutropenia and lymphopenia), and/or anemia may occur; monitoring recommended; dose adjustment may be necessary
  • Hepatic:
  • -- fatal hepatotoxicity and liver function test abnormalities may occur; monitoring recommended; interrupt, adjust, or permanently discontinue therapy based on severity of hepatic toxicity
  • Immunologic:
  • -- serious and sometimes fatal infections, including pneumonia and sepsis, have been reported
  • -- do not administer to patients with an active infection
  • Reproductive:
  • -- pregnancy should be avoided; may cause fetal harm
  • Other:
  • -- tumor lysis syndrome has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • Concomitant use
  • -- avoid coadministration with strong inhibitors of UGT1A1

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Rash (20%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Constipation (23%), Diarrhea (23%), Nausea (42%), Vomiting (29%)
  • Hematologic:Anemia (32%), Neutropenia
  • Other:Fatigue (37%), Fever (35%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Prolonged QT interval (11%)
  • Hematologic:Anemia, Grade 3 or 4 (11%), Febrile neutropenia, Leukopenia, Thrombocytopenia, Grade 3 or 4 (7%)
  • Hepatic:Liver failure, Liver function tests abnormal
  • Renal:Serum creatinine raised (More than 2%)
  • Respiratory:Pneumonia (More than 2%)
  • Other:Infectious disease (More than 2%), Multiple organ failure (More than 2%), Sepsis, Tumor lysis syndrome

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Belinostat is a histone deacetylase inhibitor that induces cell-cycle arrest and/or apoptosis of transformed cells with preferential cytotoxicity toward tumor cells via the removal of acetyl groups from lysine residues of histones and some non-histone proteins and the subsequent accumulation of acetylated histones and other proteins.

2.title: Metabolism
2.mono:
• Hepatic: extensive
  • Metabolites: belinostat amide, belinostat acid, methylbelinostat, and 3-anilinosulfonyl-benzenecarboxylic acid; activity unknown
  • Substrate primarily of UGT1A1; also a substrate of CYP2A6, CYP2C9, and CYP3A4; a likely substrate of P-glycoprotein

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Renal: less than 2% unchanged in urine
  • Total body clearance: 1240 mL/min
  • UGT1A1*28 al≤; may have reduced UGT1A1 activity; clearance may be reduced

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • use precautions for cytotoxic agents
  • reconstitute vial with 9 mL of sterile water for injection to yield 50 mg/mL solution
  • use within 12 hours of reconstitution if stored at ambient temperature (15 to 25 degrees C; 59 to 77 degrees F)
  • dilute desired dose in 250 mL NS
  • administer within 36 hours (including infusion time) if stored at ambient temperature (15 to 25 degrees C; 59 to 77 degrees F)
  • infuse via a 0.22 mcm inline filter over 30 minutes; may be extended to 45 minutes if needed

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• partial or complete tumor response is indicative of efficacy
  • blood counts, at baseline and weekly during therapy, including differential
  • liver and renal function tests, before each treatment cycle
  • tumor lysis syndrome, in patients with advanced-stage disease or high tumor burden

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct patient to report symptoms of an infection or liver toxicity.
  • Tell patient to report symptoms of thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, or anemia.
  • Advise patient to report symptoms of tumor lysis syndrome.
  • Side effects may include nausea, vomiting, pyrexia, or fatigue.
